message: I have been working with CSS for nearly 13 years and this is the first time I see that pipe attribute selector. Interesting explanation between the difference between it and the caret selector and some real live examples.
story: Ahmad Alfy shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: What is the difference between pipe (|) and caret (^) selectors?
caption: stackoverflow.com
description: As w3schools declare both | and ^ select attribute starting with a defined value So what's the difference?

data.message: That's crazy! Even crazier, since it's pretty old (as old as all other attribute selector), the support (as MDN and CanIUse put them) seems to be dated to IE 7!

It's actually CSS 2.1 ... even before the :lang selector (apparently it came to replace it) ... Before reading the examples I was like WTF why create a selector that selects what starts with characters plus the dash :D
Yeah, I'd love to know the history of this. Maybe in the days when everything was in the CSS class. Not sure, but curious.

I think it provides a more generic way to target certain languages ... Like [lang|="en"] here you don't have to worry about adding specific subset of the language -If I am allowed to call it so- e.g. en-GB, en-US ... etc. But again, that could be done using the caret selector so it's weird.
I did a little bit of research and according to this document http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/selector.html#pattern-matching ; pattern matching attribute selectors wasn't in CSS2 yet 
So at this time neither the caret selector nor the psuedo selector "lang" was available ... If you wanted to target a specific language then you had to use [lang="en"] and repeat it for every subset you are targeting. Then apparently the solution at this time was to come up with that weird pipe thing :D
